symptoms.name: Skin lesions
symptoms.severity: Variable, ranging from papules and acneiform lesions to ulcers and nodules
symptoms.pattern: Can be single or multiple, disseminated; may resemble other dermatological conditions like bacterial cellulitis, sarcoidosis, panniculitis, or molluscum contagiosum (in AIDS patients)

symptoms.name: Erythematous papules
symptoms.pattern: Well-defined, solid, regular; may be accompanied by telangiectasia and petechiae

symptoms.name: Dome-shaped papule with umbilicated center
symptoms.pattern: A typical, but not exclusive, lesion presentation

vital_signs.temperature: Elevated (hectic fever reported in severe cases)

physical_findings: Erythematous, solid, regular, and well-defined papules
Skin lesions resembling molluscum contagiosum (in AIDS patients)

lab_values.blood cultures: May show presence of Cryptococcus neoformans (but can be transient)

risk_factors: Immunosuppression (HIV, solid organ transplantation, corticosteroid use, lymphomas)
Genetic defects in the immune system (familial cases)

imaging_findings.chest x-ray: Unilateral, nodular, or cavitary infiltrates (in pulmonary cryptococcosis)
imaging_findings.PET scan: May reveal active metabolic processes in various organs (e.g., thyroid, pancreas, lungs) in disseminated disease

required: Clinical presentation consistent with cutaneous cryptococcosis
Histopathological examination showing cryptococcal organisms (e.g., using Alcian blue and mucicarmine staining)
Culture confirmation of Cryptococcus neoformans or Cryptococcus gatti
supportive: Evidence of disseminated cryptococcosis (e.g., CNS involvement, positive blood cultures, elevated serum antigen levels)
